It boils down to each individual. I don’t know too much about relationship partners, I can only tell you that what we do need as a minimum is a few genuine friends and ourselves. I’d think to tell you that, no, that it may be impossible, because I’d be thinking of the long-term. If you think that you can picture your 70-year old self, sitting alone in a couch with yourself, then I can’t say much to that. Think that you will live up to a point, and that point will eventually be becoming old and alone. You will live alone. I don’t think anyone really wants that, but it’s up to you to know. Now, if you’re asking about the present during your youth or adulthood, then, sure. It is absolutely possible. Not everyone is in need to be in a relationship, some people genuinely feel better without a partner and can just settle with their friends. We are all humans with hard-wired similarities, but we don’t all have the same needs. If you’re asking for your own self, I’d have to tell you that it won’t matter how many people you ask or how many answers you get. By the end of it all, all you need to do is ask one person, yourself, and he/she will hold all the answers which will be right for you. When you ask a question, more often than not, people will tell you things from their own personal needs. If someone can’t live without a partner, they may insist that you can’t live without one. It’s absolutely possible to be happy without one, but it’s up to you to decide what would make you a little happier.

This is more complex than it sounds. Married people are generally happier than single people, but long-time surveys show that they were already happier than average before they married. Happiness among women varies significantly more within marriage, with those in bad marriages being unhappy and those in good marriages being happy. Men are more generally happy in their marriage, and deeply unhappy after a divorce. Many divorced women are happy, but some of these still choose to marry again at a later time. Married couples who have a child usually experience a reduction in happiness that lasts for many years. They are still happier than unmarried parents. Interestingly, cohabiting couples tend to fall in between singles and married couples on the scale of happiness. It is unlikely that it is the actual wedding ritual that confers happiness, rather it seems that certain sets of the population are more likely to marry, others are more likely to cohabit without marriage, and others again more likely to remain functionally single.
